title: 1117-A
statement: A. Best Subsegmenttime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given array $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$. Find the subsegment $$$a_l, a_{l+1}, \\dots, a_r$$$ ($$$1 \\le l \\le r \\le n$$$) with maximum arithmetic mean $$$\\frac{1}{r - l + 1}\\sum\\limits_{i=l}^{r}{a_i}$$$ (in floating-point numbers, i.e. without any rounding).If there are many such subsegments find thelongestone.InputThe first line contains single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 10^5$$$) — length of the array $$$a$$$.The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$0 \\le a_i \\le 10^9$$$) — the array $$$a$$$.OutputPrint the single integer — the length of the longest subsegment with maximum possible arithmetic mean.ExampleInput5 6 1 6 6 0Output2NoteThe subsegment $$$[3, 4]$$$ is the longest among all subsegments with maximum arithmetic mean.

processed.result:
You are given an array of numbers. Find the longest subarray (a continuous sequence of numbers) within the array that has the highest average. 

The average of a subarray is calculated by summing all the numbers in the subarray and dividing by the number of elements in the subarray. 

Output the length of the longest subarray with the highest average.
Given a list of numbers, find the longest continuous section of numbers that has the highest average.
